name: 王鏊
know_by_name_description: Wang Ao was a Chinese poet and scholar from the Ming dynasty, known for his contributions to literature and his role in the cultural life of his time.
know_by_bio_summary: 王鏊（1450年—1524年），字濟之，號守溪，晚更號拙叟，学者称震泽先生，直隸蘇州府吳縣東洞庭山人，明朝正德、嘉靖年間重臣。官至戶部尚書、武英殿大學士，諡文恪。 王鏊之父王琬於成化九年（1473年），年五十五歲始授湖廣光化縣知縣，成化十三年（1477年）三月棄官歸里。王鏊自幼隨父讀書，善寫文章，國子監諸生爭誦其文。成化十年（1474年）甲午科應天鄉試第一名舉人（解元），成化十一年（1475年）聯捷乙未科會試第一名，一甲第三名進士（探花）。王鏊殿試原擬第一，一說因對策指陳時弊，為執政所忌；一說時任大學士商輅（明朝當時唯一連中三元者）不欲讓他人儷己，故抑之。授翰林院編修，歷侍講、右春坊右諭德、詹事府少詹事兼侍讀學士。弘治十三年（1500年）七月升吏部右侍郎，仍兼侍讀學士，正德元年（1506年）升吏部左侍郎，仍兼侍讀學士，十月與吏部尚書焦芳一同入閣參政，十二月升戶部尚書、文淵閣大學士、同知經筵事，正德二年（1507年）八月加少傅兼太子太傅、武英殿大學士，戶部尚書仍舊。 王鏊居官清廉，為人正直，時稱“天下窮閣老”。當時宦官劉瑾擅權，工部都水司郎中張瑋、雲南按察司副使姚祥、尚寶司卿顧璿被劉瑾荷杖幾死，王鏊怒斥劉瑾：“士可殺，不可辱。今辱且殺之，吾尚何顏居此。”與前戶部尚書韓文等上疏請誅劉瑾等“八黨”，不被採納，正德四年（1509年）四月致仕歸里，讀書著作，常與詩友遊山玩水，學者稱震澤先生。閒居十四年，嘉靖三年（1524年）卒，追贈太傅，諡文恪。 致仕後，在蘇州學士街天官坊建有“怡老園”，清朝改作江蘇布政使司衙門。 著有《詩文集》36卷、《奏疏》2卷、《守溪筆記》2卷、《震澤紀聞》2卷、《震澤長語》2卷、《震澤編》8卷、《姑蘇志》60卷、《春秋詞命》3卷、《本草單方》8卷，並參與纂修《明孝宗實錄》224卷。 祖王伯英，祖王惟道，父王朝用，官光化知县，皆以子贵，赠如其官。曾祖妣陆氏、祖妣叶氏、妣叶氏，皆一品夫人。 王鏊故里陸巷有惠和堂以及解元、會元、探花牌樓。其墓在東洞庭山梁家山。
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized:
Wang Ao (1450 - 1524), styled Ji Zhi, with the pseudonym Shou Xi, later known as Zhuo Sou, was a scholar referred to as Mr. Zhen Ze. He hailed from the eastern region of a fictional mountain in the province of Suzhou during the Ming Dynasty's Zhengde and Jiajing eras. He rose to the position of Minister of Revenue and Grand Scholar of the Wu Ying Hall, posthumously honored as Wen Ke.

Wang Ao's father, Wang Wan, began his career as the magistrate of a fictional county in the ninth year of the Chenghua era (1473) at the age of fifty-five, but resigned in the thirteenth year (1477) to return home. From a young age, Wang Ao studied with his father and excelled in writing, with students competing to recite his works. In the tenth year of Chenghua (1474), he topped the local examination, and in the eleventh year (1475), he excelled in the national examination, ranking third among the top scholars.

Wang Ao was originally expected to rank first in the palace examination, but it is said that he was suppressed due to his outspoken criticism of current issues, or that the then Grand Scholar, Shang Lu, who had achieved the highest honors, did not want to share the spotlight. He was appointed as an editor in the Hanlin Academy, serving in various roles including lecturer and vice minister of the Ministry of Rites. In the thirteenth year of Hongzhi (1500), he was promoted to Deputy Minister of Personnel while still serving as a scholar. In the first year of Zhengde (1506), he became the Left Deputy Minister of Personnel and continued as a scholar. In October, he entered the cabinet alongside the Minister of Personnel, Jiao Fang, and in December, he was promoted to Minister of Revenue and Grand Scholar of the Wen Yuan Pavilion, also overseeing the Imperial Academy.

Wang Ao was known for his integrity and was often referred to as "the old man of the poor in the world." During the time when the eunuch Liu Jin held power, several officials were nearly killed by him. Wang Ao angrily rebuked Liu Jin, stating, "Scholars can be killed, but not humiliated. Now, to humiliate and kill them, how can I face this?" Along with former Minister of Revenue Han Wen and others, he petitioned for the punishment of Liu Jin and his associates, but it was not accepted. In the fourth year of Zhengde (1509), he retired and returned home to read and write, often enjoying nature with friends, earning the title Mr. Zhen Ze among scholars. After fourteen years of leisure, he passed away in the third year of Jiajing (1524) and was posthumously honored as Grand Tutor, with the title Wen Ke.

After retirement, he built the "Yi Lao Garden" in a fictional street in Suzhou, which was later transformed into a government office during the Qing Dynasty. He authored several works, including a collection of poetry, memorials, and notes, and participated in the compilation of a historical record.

His ancestors included Wang Bo Ying and Wang Wei Dao, with his father Wang Zhao Yong serving as the magistrate of a fictional county, all honored posthumously. His great-grandmothers and grandmothers were all of noble status. Wang Ao's hometown features a hall and archways commemorating top scholars. His tomb is located in a fictional mountain area.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The biography describes a historical figure named Wang Ao, detailing his life, achievements, and contributions during the Ming Dynasty. The specific dates, titles, and events mentioned align with the known history of Wang Ao, a prominent scholar and official of that era.

name: 张永
know_by_bio_summary: 張永（1465年—1529年），保定人。明武宗時的司礼监太监。 成化元年，出生。成化十一年，选入内廷。八虎之一，與劉瑾有怨懟，劉瑾打算將之黜發南京，於是兩人在皇帝面前對質。張永動手痛毆劉瑾，武宗令谷大用等置酒勸和。安化王朱寘鐇反叛，明武宗派楊一清總督寧夏、延綏，由張永任楊一清監軍。不久朱寘鐇被楊一清俘獲，張永趁獻俘時向武宗告發劉瑾罪狀，明武宗命令張永帶領禁軍捉拿劉瑾。最後劉瑾被殺。 正德十四年（1519年），寧王朱宸濠謀反，明武宗親征，命張永率邊兵兩千人為前鋒。王守仁將朱宸濠俘虜，交付張永。江彬欲誣王守仁謀反，被張永救解得免。明世宗即位後，八虎受到打擊，御史萧淮彈劾谷大用、丘聚等人蛊惑先帝，並牽連張永。世宗下诏命张永闲住。萧淮又弹劾张永在江西有违法事，贬为奉御，前往孝陵主持香光。嘉靖五年，召还京师。嘉靖六年，为御用监掌印太监。嘉靖八年（1529年），大学士杨一清等說張永實有功，遂起用掌管御用监，提督团营。不久死去。 [在维基数据编辑]
know_by_bio_summary_anonymized: Zhang Long (Year 1465 - Year 1529), from Baoding. A eunuch in the Imperial Secretariat during the reign of Emperor Wu. Born in the first year of the Chenghua era. Selected to the inner court in the eleventh year of Chenghua. One of the Eight Tigers, he had a grudge against Liu Jin, who planned to exile him to Nanjing, leading to a confrontation before the emperor. Zhang Long physically assaulted Liu Jin, prompting Emperor Wu to have Gu Dayong and others host a banquet to mediate. When Prince Anhua rebelled, Emperor Wu dispatched Yang Yiqing to oversee Ningxia and Yansui, with Zhang Long appointed as Yang Yiqing's military supervisor. Soon, Prince Anhua was captured by Yang Yiqing, and during the presentation of the captive, Zhang Long reported Liu Jin's crimes to Emperor Wu, who ordered Zhang Long to lead the imperial troops to apprehend Liu Jin. Ultimately, Liu Jin was executed. In the fourteenth year of the Zhengde era (Year 1519), Prince Ning plotted a rebellion, and Emperor Wu personally led a campaign, commanding Zhang Long to lead two thousand border troops as the vanguard. Wang Shouren captured Prince Ning and handed him over to Zhang Long. Jiang Bin attempted to falsely accuse Wang Shouren of rebellion but was saved by Zhang Long. After Emperor Shizong ascended the throne, the Eight Tigers faced setbacks, and Censor Xiao Huai impeached Gu Dayong, Qiu Ju, and others for misleading the late emperor, implicating Zhang Long as well. Shizong issued an edict ordering Zhang Long to be placed on leave. Xiao Huai further accused Zhang Long of illegal activities in Jiangxi, demoting him to a ceremonial position at Xiaoling. In the fifth year of the Jiajing era, he was recalled to the capital. In the sixth year of Jiajing, he became the chief eunuch in charge of the imperial seal. In the eighth year of Jiajing (Year 1529), Grand Scholar Yang Yiqing and others argued that Zhang Long had indeed contributed, leading to his appointment to manage the imperial eunuch office and oversee the military camps. He soon passed away.
know_by_bio_reasoning: The biography describes a historical figure named Zhang Long, detailing his life as a eunuch in the Imperial Secretariat during the Ming Dynasty, specifically under Emperor Wu. The events and titles mentioned, such as being part of the Eight Tigers and his interactions with Liu Jin and Prince Anhua, align with known historical accounts of Zhang Long's life and role in the Ming court.
